coredata.dc:title: High-resolution and symmetry-resolved oxygen K-edge spectra of O2
coredata.dc:creator: Kosugi, Nobuhiro
Shigemasa, Eiji
Yagishita, Akira
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
High-resolution ion-yield and electron-yield spectra and “symmetry-resolved” ion-yield spectra have been measured at the O K-edge of O2. The 1s—π* (3Π) and 1s—σ* (3Σ−) bound-state resonances are clearly resolved, where the σ* resonance is split into two features. Many Rydberg transitions converging to the 4Σ− and 2Σ− ionization thresholds are found on the 1s—σ* resonance, but above the 4Σ− threshold the Rydberg series converging to the 2Σ− threshold show only a broad band. They are interpreted with the help of ab initio SCF-CI and frozen-core calculations for the core-excited states with four open shells. The Rydberg series are assigned to the 1s—3sσ, 1s—3pπ, and 1s—npσ (n = 3, 4, …) transitions. The splitting of the σ* resonance arises from the exchange interaction; however, in contrast with the Rydberg states, the core-to-valence (1s—σ*) excited state related to the 2Σ− spin coupling is lower in energy than the 1s—σ* state related to the 4Σ− one.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 High-resolution and symmetry-resolved oxygen K-edge spectra of 02 Nobuhiro Kosugi Division ofMolecularEngineering, Kyoto University, Yoshida, Kyoto 606, Japan Eiji Shigemasa and Akira Yagishita Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba 305, Japan Received 28 October 1991; in final form 26 November 1991 High-resolution ion-yield and electron-yield spectra and "symmetry-resolved" ion-yield spectra have been measured at the O K-edge of 02. The ls-7c* ('II) and ls-a* ('E-) bound-state resonances are clearly resolved, where the a* resonance is split into two features. Many Rydberg transitions converging to the E- and 2E- ionization thresholds are found on the l s-a* resonance, but above the 'E- threshold the Rydberg series converging to the ZE- threshold show only a broad band. They are interpreted with the help of ab initio SCF-CI and frozen-core calculations for the core-excited states with four open shells. The Rydberg series are assigned to the I s-3sa, I s-3pn, and 1 s-npa (n = 3, 4, ...) transitions. The splitting of the a* resonance arises from the exchange interaction; however, in contrast with the Rydberg states, the core-to-valence (Is-a*) excited state related to the 2E- spin coupling is lower in energy than the 1 s-a* state related to the E- one. 1. Introduction Inner-shell excitation spectroscopy for atomic and molecular systems has been performed intensively during the last two decades since Nakamura et al. revealed Rydberg series in the nitrogen K-edge of NZ in 1969 [ 1 ]. Electron-energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) is a powerful and convenient technique to investigate the inner-shell excitation with moderate energy resolution. High-resolution EELS is possible [ 2, 3 ] but not so widely used because the cross sections are small, resulting in low signal count rates. Especially in the O K-edge region, it is not feasible because of the large decrease in signal intensity at higher-energy losses. On the other hand, photoabsorption spectroscopy has no special problem with the signal count rates at higher photon energies, but high-resolution monochromators were not available until recently. High-resolution photoabsorption spectroscopy has been initiated with the Dragon monochromator at NSLS [4,5]. Now, inner-shell spectroscopy with comparably high resolution is attainable also at the LBL 55 m SGM of SSRL [6], 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. SX700/11 of BESSY [ 7 ], and 10 m GIM of KEKPF [8]. In addition to high-resolution inner-shell spectroscopy, some new techniques in angle-resolved spectroscopy of polarized decay channels after photoabsorption have been recently developed using linearly polarized synchrotron radiation. One is angleresolved ion-yield spectroscopy [ 9-12 ] and the other is angle-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy [ 13,14 ] . Both techniques can reveal symmetries of the final states of the photoabsorption process by measuring the anisotropic angular distribution of the fragment ions, i.e., the asymmetry parameter, and by measuring the degree and orientation of the polarized fluorescence, respectively. More recently, "symmetryresolved" N K-edge absorption spectra of NZ have been successfully measured by using angle-resolved ion-yield spectroscopy [ 15 ] . In the present work, the O K-edge spectra of OZ have been measured using "symmetry-resolved" ionyield spectroscopy [ 15,16 ] and high-resolution ionyield and electron-yield spectroscopy [ 16 ] . This combination yields detailed information about the 481 Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 electronic structure of the core-excited states. Furthermore, the bound-state resonances and Rydberg excited states are investigated with ab initio quantum-chemical calculations. Features of the core-excited states with four open shells are revealed. 2. Methods Photoabsorption experiments were performed at Beamline 2B of the Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, The beamline has a 10 m grazing-incidence monochromator combined with a 60-period soft X-ray undulator. In the energy range around the oxygen K-edge, a 2400 Q/mm grating was used. Polypropylene film, about 5000 A thick, was used to separate the different pressure regions of the experimental chamber and the monochromator. Details of the beamline are described elsewhere [ 8 ] . A time-of-flight spectrometer was used to measure high-resolution total-electron and total-ion yield spectra [ 16 ] . A drift tube of 44 cm length acts as an angular limiter for fragment ions emitted perpendicularly to the drift tube, resulting in a slightly reduced contribution from decay channels after 1 s-n (A1= + 1) absorption. Another type of photoion spectrometer was used to measure "symmetry-resolved" photoabsorption spectra [ 15,16 ] . This spectrometer consists of two identical parallel-plate electrostatic energy analyzers with position-sensitive detectors. They were positioned parallel and perpendicular to the electric vector of the synchrotron radiation to measure simultaneously the two decay channels after the 1 s-n (A1= + 1) and 1 s-ss (A1=0) absorption. The energy analyzers were operated to collect ions with energies higher than 2 eV. The core-ionized 4E- and ZE- states were obtained by an ab initio SCF method based on the localized-core hole picture [ 17 ] . The 1 s-2pn* (1 ng ) 'II state, which is described by a single Slater determinant, was also calculated by the SCF method with the localized core. On the other hand, the 1 s-2pss* (36 ) triplet-excited configurations with four open shells yield two 3E-, one 3A (degenerate) and one s1+ states, of which the 3E- states are dipole-allowed. The 3E- states were obtained by a small CI calculation using only the open-shell SCF orbitals of the highest-spin SE- state with the localized core. The 482 core-to-Rydberg 'II and 3E- excited states were obtained with the frozen-core approximation using the core-ionized E- and ZE- SCF configurations as ionic cores, where the method based on the frozen-core approximation [ 18 ] was newly developed for the open-shell systems. In the frozen-core calculations, the Rydberg orbitals were orthogonalized with the 2pss* SCF orbital in the 1 s-2pss* (SE-) state. This procedure is necessary to avoid spurious mixing between Rydberg and valence orbitals and to ensure the orthogonalization between the core-to-valence and core-to-Rydberg states. It was confirmed by the CI calculations that the configuration mixing in the two Rydberg states converging to the 4E- and zEionization thresholds was small. Primitive basis functions were taken from (73/7) contracted Gaussian-type functions of Huzinaga et al. [ 19 ] . They were augmented with two d polarization functions: ~a=2.704 and 0.535. The contraction schemes were (4111111 / 31111 / 1 * 1 *) and (721 / 511 / 1 * 1 *) for the ionized and unionized oxygen atoms, respectively; in the former basis, the innermost 2s exponent was changed to 2.00392 from 10.19552. To describe 3s-6s, 3p-6p, 3d-5d Rydberg orbitals, the exponents were optimized in the 'II or SE- states with the frozen-core approximation using the core-ionized 4E- SCF configuration as the ionic core. The resultant exponents were as follows: 0.027, 0.0064, 0.0022 and 0.0012; CP=0.020, 0.0056, 0.0020 and 0.0011; Ca=0.012, 0.0034 and 0.0015. Furthermore, to improve description of the inner part of Rydberg orbitals, the following primitive functions were added on the ionized atom: C5=0.075, ~P=0.048, and Ca=0.035. The total number of basis functions was 94. The calculations were performed by using the originally developed code GSCF3 [20,21 ] on a MIPS RS3230 workstation. 3. Results and discussion 1.1. Core-to-valence excitations Fig. 1 shows "symmetry-resolved" O K-edge spectra of OZ with 950 meV fwhm. The ls-ss (A1=0) and 1 s-n (Al = + 1) excitations are not completely resolved due to the imperfect polarization degree Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 2Pr 525 535 545 555 565 Photon Energy (eVl Fig. 1. Symmetry-resolved ion-yield spectra at the O K-edge of 02 measured with moderate energy resolution. The solid line and dashed line correspond to the decay channels after the ls-n (AA =+1) and ls-a (0,1=0) excitations, respectively. The lines marked 'E- and zE' indicate the energy positions of the ionization thresholds. (;t~ 95%) of the monochromatized photons at 530.5 eV. In the E (D<1=0 ) spectrum, two ss resonances are observed at about 539.5 and 542 eV, where the intensity of the higher resonance is larger than the lower one. No prominent ss resonance is observed above the ionization threshold. In the II (D<1= + 1) spectrum, a single n resonance is strongly observed at 530.5 eV. The present result is consistent with the angular dependence of NEXAFS spectra of physisorbed and chemisorbed OZ on Pt (111) [22]. It is reasonable that the 7c resonance is assigned to the 1 s1 ng ( 2pn* ) bound-state transition [ 23 ] and the main features of the a resonance are assigned to the ls3e,~ ( 2pss* ) bound-state transitions [221 (not to Rydberg [23]). In the a* resonance region, the 1 s-n (AA = + 1 ) contribution is gradually increasing towards the continuum. There should be core-to-Rydberg transitions in this region, though no fine structure is resolved due to the low energy resolution. There are two Rydberg series converging to the ^E- and ZE- ionization thresholds as indicated in fig. 1; therefore, the higher and weak 1 s-npa Rydberg transitions converging to the 4E- ionization threshold are superimposed on the lower and intense Rydberg transitions converging to the zE- one, and the higher transitions converging to the ZE- one are superimposed on the 4W continuum. Thus, it is reasonable that the II ( AA = + 1) spectrum at the ss* resonance region is attributed to the 1 s-npic Rydberg transitions. The II (A.A= + 1) contribution becomes twice the E (D<1=0 ) one at about + I S eV above the threshold; on the other hand, in the N K-edge of N2, the two contributions are almost equal even at about +20 eV above the threshold [ 15]. This means that the convergence to the statistical ratio ( 2:1) in the O K-edge of OZ is much faster than in the N K-edge of Nz. This is consistent with the fact that above the threshold, there is no resonance structure in 02 but a strong ss shape resonance in N2- Table 1 summarizes the calculated results for the core-to-valence excitations and the core ionization. The excitation and ionization energies calculated with the localized-core hole picture are in good agreement with the experimental ones. The ground state of Oz is 3E g ( SZ= 1, 0 ) with two open shells, and the dipole-allowed excited states are 3II and 3E(SZ= 1, 0) with four open shells which correspond to 3II and 3EU in the D-,, symmetry. For simplicity, let us discuss SZ=1 spin-coupled configurations. Discussion based on SZ=0 configurations will yield the same conclusion. The 31- ground-state wavefunction (SZ=1) is mainly described by a single configuration 3Oo, 3 Oo = ccxy [ assaa J where c, x and y denote core (Is) and n* (x=icX, y=><y) orbitals, and ccxy and [assaa] denote the orbital and spin products, respectively. The coreionized states allowed from the ground state 3Oo (SZ-1) correspond to the 'Y.- (SZ=3/2, 1/2) and ZE- (SZ=1 /2 ) states as follows: 'OH(ss) (SZ=3/2)=cxY[aaaJ, 'Op(oo)(SZ=1/2)=cxy[ssaa+assa+aass]/ f , ZOH(oo)(SZ=1/2)=cxy[2ssaa-a(ssa+ass)]/ f where the 'E- configuration state functions are degenerate in the absence of a magnetic field. The exchange splitting between the ZE- and 4E- configuration state functions is given by DEeXc,,(o0)=31X(=3Ky)z 1.1 eV (exp.) , 0.80 eV (calc. ) , where K$b is an exchange integral between a and b. The calculated exchange splitting underestimates the experimental value [ 24 ] but the agreement is im- 483 Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 Table 1 Calculated results for bound-state resonances and ionizations of the O K-edge of Oz. [ 24 ]. The experimental excitation energies of the 1 s-a* bound-state resonances correspond to the centroid of the broad bands. proved in comparison with the previously reported result (0.61 eV) [17]. The ls-a* triplet excited state (Sz=1) involves the following five configuration state functions o 2.5 (exp. ) (V=ts*): 3Op(V)=Vcxy[3ssaaa -a(ssaa+assa+aass) ]/ 12 , 3OB(v)=vcxy[2assaa-a (ass+ssa)]/f , 'OC (V) =Vcxy [ as ( ass- ssa ) ] /~,/2 , 'OD(V)=Vc(xx-yy) [a""ss]/,/2, 'OE(V)=Vc(xx+yy) [aaass]/.~2. The 3Op ( V ) and 3OB ( V ) configuration state func tions have the dipole-allowed 3E- symmetry, where the core and n* electrons are coupled with the quar tet ('E- ) and doublet (ZE- ) spins; the other con figuration state functions, 30C (V), 3 (DD (V) and 3OE (V), have singlet-coupled ('O and 'E+) n* elec trons and belong to the dipole-forbidden 30 (degen erate) and 'E+ symmetries, respectively. The Ham iltonian matrix element between 3Op ( V ) and 3OB ( V ) is small ( o 0.02 eV), and the two eigen states of the 1 s-a* triplet excited states are described approximately by 3Op ( V ) and 3OB ( V ), respectively. The exchange splitting and transition matrix ele ments are given as follows: 484 aEexch(V)=E13OA(V)J EL3OB(V)I 3K,Y + 3Kvx + 31iv~ x2.75 eV (calc.) , <'(DO Ir13OA(v))~-2<cIrIV>/.,/3, <3OoJr13OB(V)i^ 2<ci ri V> /,/6. The calculated splitting is in good agreement with the observation. The exchange integrals between the valence orbitals and between the core ( lsa) and a* (= V ) orbitals, KvX ( o 1.2 eV) and Kve ( z 1.1 eV), are significantly larger than the integral between the core and n* orbitals, KeX ( ~t 0.3 eV). Therefore, the 'OB ( V ) configuration state function is lower in energy than 3Op ( V ). The probability for the lower 1 sa* transition 3Oo-> 3OB ( V ) is smaller than that for the higher one 'Oo-> 3Op ( V ), where the ratio becomes 1:2 if no configuration mixing between 3Op ( V ) and 3OB ( V ) is taken into account. This prediction is in agreement with the observation. Although there have been several interpretations [3,5,22,23,25,26] proposed to explain the unusual shape of the ss* resonance, the present theoretical consideration clearly shows that the ss* resonance is split by the exchange interaction. Wurth et al. [ 22 ] have recently calculated the 1 s-a* transition energies and probabilities based on the Xa method and reported that the exchange splitting is 1.2 eV and the lower state has larger intensity than the higher state. That quantitative disagreement is probably due to incorrect exchange interaction between the config- Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 uration state functions wit four open shells. 3.2. Core-to-Rydberg excitations Figs. 2 and 3 show high-resolution O K-edge electron-yield and ion-yield spectra of Oz with o 50 meV fwhm, respectively. The resolution is better than that of a recently published spectrum [ 5 ] . The fine structure is clearly observed on the 1 s-2pa* bound-state resonances and corresponds to two Rydberg series converging to the 4E- and zE- ionization thresholds, 543.1 and 544.2 eV [24]. It is interesting that between the 4E- and zE- thresholds, the Rydberg states converging to the 2E- ionized state almost disappear and only show a broad band through the interaction with the 4E- continuum. There is some dif- L__~ 02 Rydberg Series L 536 538 540 542 Photon Energy (eVl 544 546 Fig. 2. High-resolution electron-yield spectrum at the O K-edge of OZ. The Rydberg transitions are observed in the ls-2pa* resonance region. 540 542 Photon Energy leVl I 544 546 Fig. 3. High-resolution ion-yield spectrum at the O K-edge of OZ. The contribution from the t s-n (AA - + 1) excitation is slightly reduced in the present experimental condition (see text). ference found between the electron-yield and ionyield spectra; peak nos. 5 and 9 are weakened in the ion-yield spectrum. In the ion-yield spectrum, the contribution from the l s-7< (AA =+ 1) excitation is slightly suppressed in the present experimental conditions for the orientation of the drift tube and the polarization of the light source; therefore, peak nos. 5 and 9 come from 1 s-n n absorption and all the other peaks come mainly from 1 s-n a. This prediction disagrees with the previous interpretation that the 1 snpn series is dominant [ 5 ] . The ion-yield spectrum is slightly weakened in the higher energy region due to slightly reduced n contribution (see fig. 1). From the viewpoint of the overall structure, however, the ion-yield spectrum resembles the photoabsorption spectrum [ 5 ] much more than the electron-yield spectrum; that is, in the electron-yield spectrum, the higher ss* band ( 3OA ( V ) ) is relatively strengthened. This might be partly because a channel to twos-tep autoionization is open at the higher ss* band. Table 2 shows the results of frozen-core calculations for the Rydberg transitions. The triplet Rydberg states (S. =I) allowed from the ground state 'Oo ( SZ=1) are described approximately by the following configuration state functions: 3OA( R ) =Rcxy [ 3ssaaa -a(ss a+assa+aass)]/ 12> 3OB(R)=Rcxy[2ass -aa(ass+ssa)]/f , which have the same 3E- and 'II symmetries when the Rydberg orbitals ( R ) are ss-type and n-type, respectively. The 3OA ( R ) and 3OB ( R ) Rydberg states converge to the 4E- ('O,_,, 'OA ) and 21:- ( 2OB ) ionized states, respectively. In the 'II symmetry, there are two additional configuration state functions which have singlet-coupled ('D and 'E+) 2pn* electrons; however, their configuration mixing with the dipole-allowed configuration state functions 3OA ( R ) and 3OB ( R ) is very small, resulting in no transition probability. The exchange splitting between 3OA ( R ) and 'OB ( R ) is approximately given by AFexch(R)=3xss-6(ligx+ARY)-3KRcn where the sum of the second and third terms is at most 0.11 eV ( R= 3s) and AE, xen ( R ) is nearly the same as AEexch ( 00 ). This is consistent with the result 485 Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 Table 2 Calculated results for the core-to-Rydberg transitions of the O K-edge of Oz. I 0) 0.00002 5 4da 0.80 (4.12) 0.000025 0.81 (4.11) 0.000014 5da 0.51 (5.14) 0.000016 0.52 (5.13) 0.000008 16-3pn 2.58 (2.30) 0.000180 2.66 (2.26) 0.000135 4p7c 1.23 (3.32) 0.000068 1.26 (3.28) 0.000051 5pic 0.73 (4.33) 0.000030 0.74 (4.30) 0.000022 6p7c 0.48 (5.35) 0.000017 0.48 (5.32) 0.000012 1 a-3drc 1.43 (3.09) 0.000073 1.43 (3.08) 0.000041 4d7c 0.81 (4.10) 0.000033 0.81 (4.09) 0.000019 5d7c 0.52 (5.12) 0.000017 0.52 (5.11) 0.000010 that the Hamiltonian matrix element between 3OA (R) and 3OB (R) is very small. The effective quantum numbers and the oscillator strengths show ordinary and uniform behavior within each Rydberg series, indicating that the Gaussian basis functions are well optimized. It is interesting that the quantum defects for the npn series (x 0.7) are rather larger than those for the npss ones ( & 0.5 ). This is characteristic of the OZ molecule [ 27 ] . The result for the oscillator strengths indicates that the 1 s-npss series are dominant, and the 1 s-3sa and 1 s3pn transitions are also observable. This is consistent with the experimental prediction based on the comparison of the ion-yield and electron-yield spectra. When the same Rydberg orbitals are used, the ratio of the oscillator strengths between the 3Op--ss 3OA (R) and 3OB (R) transitions is calculated as 2 : 1. In the present work, the Rydberg orbitals are optimized for each threshold, and the ratio deviates from 2: 1. Near the threshold, however, the ratio seems to approach 2 : 1. Table 3 summarizes the experimental results for the Rydberg transitions and their assignment based on the experimental and theoretical prediction. The fine structure on the 1 s-a* bound-state resonances 486 can be interpreted by the Rydberg transitions 1 s-> 3sa (-lsss -+3sae), Is-a3pn (-lsssg- 3pn ), and 1 s-> npss ( - 1 sag, npss ) (n = 3, 4, ...) . The assignment of peak no. 1 to peak no. 9 agrees with the previous one [ 5 ] except that the present work predicts that there are more vibrational structures and the 3d and 4s contributions are very small. The 1 s-3sss, 1 s3pa, and 1 s-4pss transitions show vibrational structures, though there are other possibilities; for example, peak no. 1 to peak no. 4 might be assigned to the vibrational structures of the 1 s-a* excited state (3OB (V)) . The frequencies are ~ 0.24-0.20 e V, which are comparable with the stretching frequencies of the neutral and cationic ground states (0.196 and 0.233 eV). There are some discrepancies noticed between the experiment and the calculation. The calculated term values are smaller than the experimental ones. This is partly because the dynamical polarization of the ion core by the Rydberg electrons cannot be taken into account in the frozen-core approximation. Furthermore, the Is-3sss and Is-3pn transitions seem to have much larger intensity than predicted. To improve the prediction, we have to go beyond the frozen-core approximation and take into account perturbation by the valence-Rydberg mixing Volume 190, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 13 March 1992 Table 3 Energies and assignments of the Rydberg transitions in the O K-edge spectra of OZ. For example, the Rydberg transitions to the 3OA(R) states can have larger intensity than predicted, because the 'OA (V) 1 s-ss* state is higher in energy than some 3OA (R) Rydberg states and there should be some valence mixing. head.ce:title: High-resolution and symmetry-resolved oxygen K-edge spectra of O2

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Division of Molecular Engineering, Kyoto University, Yoshida, Kyoto 606, Japan
Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba 305, Japan

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: High-resolution ion-yield and electron-yield spectra and “symmetry-resolved” ion-yield spectra have been measured at the O K-edge of O2. The 1s—π* (3Π) and 1s—σ* (3Σ−) bound-state resonances are clearly resolved, where the σ* resonance is split into two features. Many Rydberg transitions converging to the 4Σ− and 2Σ− ionization thresholds are found on the 1s—σ* resonance, but above the 4Σ− threshold the Rydberg series converging to the 2Σ− threshold show only a broad band. They are interpreted with the help of ab initio SCF-CI and frozen-core calculations for the core-excited states with four open shells. The Rydberg series are assigned to the 1s—3sσ, 1s—3pπ, and 1s—npσ (n = 3, 4, …) transitions. The splitting of the σ* resonance arises from the exchange interaction; however, in contrast with the Rydberg states, the core-to-valence (1s—σ*) excited state related to the 2Σ− spin coupling is lower in energy than the 1s—σ* state related to the 4Σ− one.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Synchrotron Radiation Instrumentation, Chester

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: E. Shigemasa, K. Ueda, Y. Sato, T. Sasaki and A. Yagishita, Phys. Rev. A, submitted for publication.
A. Yagishita and E. Shigemasa, Rev. Sci. Instr., in press.
